docs.lead_paragraph: THE grammar school at St. Lawrence O'Toole Roman Catholic parish here opened in 1926, in a two-story building at the crest of a gentle slope near the train station. For decades, nuns lived in the rooms upstairs and taught their students in classrooms on the first floor.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE six Roman Catholic elementary schools here had struggled for more than a decade to meet enrollment goals. Tuition kept them out of reach for at least the one in five local families who lived below the poverty line, and their rising operating costs strained the finances of parishes already finding it difficult to make ends meet.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE six Roman Catholic elementary schools in Bridgeport, Conn., had struggled for more than a decade to meet enrollment goals. Tuition kept them out of reach for at least the one in five local families who lived below the poverty line, and their rising operating costs strained the finances of parishes already finding it hard to make ends meet. In 2004, Bishop William E. Lori, who had replaced Cardinal Edward M. Egan as head of the Diocese of Bridgeport, issued a call to action. He enlisted the help of retired chief executives and fund-raising specialists, who then recruited patrons for the schools or school projects, like maintenance and library renovation. He met with pastors of African-American churches and told them that their children were welcome in the Catholic schools. And he advertised to Latino families on Spanish-language radio.

docs.lead_paragraph: CLEAR CHANNEL TRIAL A Texas judge refused on Friday a request by several New York-based banks to dismiss a lawsuit filed by Clear Channel Communications and two buyout firms trying to acquire the radio operator. Judge Joe F. Brown Jr. of Bexar County State District Court set a June 2 trial date for the case. The private equity firms Thomas H. Lee Partners and Bain Capital had filed complaints in New York and Texas against Citigroup, Morgan Stanley, Credit Suisse, Royal Bank of Scotland, Deutsche Bank and Wachovia, seeking to force them to finance a $20 billion buyout of Clear Channel. (REUTERS)
docs.abstract: Texas Judge Joe F Brown Jr refuses request by several New York-based banks to dismiss lawsuit filed by Clear Channel Communications and buyout firms Thomas H Lee Partners and Bain Capital trying to acquire radio operator; private equity firms are trying to force banks to finance $20 billion buyout (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo has expanded his investigation into an alleged pension fraud scheme to include scores of lawyers and school districts accused of having bilked the state out of tens of millions of dollars in benefits.
